Arbitrary beam control using passive lossless metasurfaces enabled by orthogonally-polarized custom surface waves

Do-Hoon Kwon dhkwon@umass.edu Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Amherst, Massachusetts 01003, USA    Sergei A. Tretyakov Department of Electronics and Nanoengineering, Aalto University, P.O. Box 15500, 00076 Aalto, Finland
Abstract

For passive, lossless impenetrable metasurfaces, a design technique for arbitrary beam control of receiving, guiding, and launching is presented. Arbitrary control is enabled by a custom surface wave in an orthogonal polarization such that its addition to the incident (input) and the desired scattered (output) fields is supported by a reactive surface impedance everywhere on the reflecting surface. Such a custom surface wave (SW) takes the form of an evanescent wave propagating along the surface with a spatially varying envelope. A growing SW appears when an illuminating beam is received. The SW amplitude stays constant when power is guided along the surface. The amplitude diminishes as a propagating wave (PW) is launched from the surface as a leaky wave. The resulting reactive tensor impedance profile may be realized as an array of anisotropic metallic resonators printed on a grounded dielectric substrate. Illustrative design examples of a Gaussian beam translator-reflector, a probe-fed beam launcher, and a near-field focusing lens are provided.

I Introduction

Comprising an electrically thin layer of subwavelength resonators Holloway et al. (2012), metasurfaces are capable of tailoring the characteristics of propagating and evanescent waves with a significantly reduced loss compared with traditional volumetric metamaterials. In particular, gradient metasurfaces, those with spatially varying surface parameters, have received increased attention in recent years. By imparting a linearly gradient discontinuity on a reflection or transmission phase, the incident wave can be deflected anomalously upon reflection or transmission. Since a recent formalization of the generalized laws of reflection and refraction Yu et al. (2011), a wide variety of novel metasurface applications have been proposed and demonstrated. Using penetrable metasurfaces, anomalous refraction has been demonstrated from microwave to optical regimes Yu et al. (2011); Aieta et al. (2012); Pfeiffer and Grbic (2013); Wong et al. (2015); Asadchy et al. (2015). Introducing a proper nonlinear phase distribution leads to lenses Monticone et al. (2013); Lin et al. (2014); Wang et al. (2015); Khorasaninejad et al. (2016). Holograms are designed by locally controlling the transmission amplitude and/or phase Ni et al. (2013); Huang et al. (2013). A careful geometrical arrangement of transmission blocks having different transmission phases can create optical vortex beams Yu et al. (2011); Genevet et al. (2012); Karimi et al. (2014); Shalaev et al. (2015); Chong et al. (2015).

A variety of novel functionalities have also been demonstrated in the reflection mode or for impenetrable metasurfaces. Anomalous reflection described by the generalized Snell’s law has been in use for reflectarray designs in the antenna engineering community Huang and Encinar (2008). Reflection-mode lenses Pors et al. (2013); Asadchy et al. (2015), holograms Zheng et al. (2015); Wen et al. (2015), and optical vortex generator Yang et al. (2014); Yu et al. (2016) have been reported. In Sun et al. (2012a), conversion from a plane wave into an SW was cast as a special case of anomalous reflection, wherein the reflected wave vector enters the evanescent (invisible) spectral range. This work has spurred a strong interest in the conversion process and efficiency between propagating and evanescent waves Sun et al. (2012b); Wang et al. (2012); Pors et al. (2014); Fan et al. (2016), either in the form of surface plasmon polariton waves at optical frequencies or SWs at microwave frequencies. In addition, gradient metasurfaces raised a renewed interest in improving traditional leaky-wave antennas based on arrays of subwavelength printed resonators on a grounded dielectric substrate Fong et al. (2010); Patel and Grbic (2011); Minatti et al. (2016a, b). For nonlinear metasurfaces, design of proper phase distributions associated with a judicious choice of nonlinear meta-atom arrangement can manipulate beams such as steering, splitting, focusing, and vortex generation at harmonic frequencies Segal et al. (2015); Wolf et al. (2015); Almeida et al. (2016); Tymchenko et al. (2016). If the required grating period allows no more than three propagating Floquet modes, anomalous reflection with nearly unitary efficiency can be realized using a few or even a single inclusion per period, using blazed gratings Loewen et al. (1977) or recent conceptualizations such as meta-gratings Ra’di et al. (2017) and agressively discretized metasurfaces Wong and Eleftheriades (2017).

Along with the designs and demonstrations of novel wave transformations, their efficiencies started to receive attention. Toward complete wavefront tailoring via a complete 2​π2𝜋2\pi transmission phase coverage, the generalized Snell’s laws were demonstrated using cross-polarized light in Yu et al. (2011); Aieta et al. (2012). It was theoretically revealed that the maximum power coupling efficiency is only 25% Monticone et al. (2013). Utilizing a balanced pair of induced tangential electric and magnetic dipole moments, Huygens’ metasurfaces Pfeiffer and Grbic (2013); Wong et al. (2015) can achieve polarization-preserving full transmission with an arbitrary phase in a complete 2​π2𝜋2\pi span. At microwave frequencies, low-loss conductor trances can be arranged to realize the electric and magnetic dipoles. In the optical regime, a careful choice of the dimensions, shape, material, and periodicity for an array of dielectric resonator meta-atoms can bring the electric and magnetic dipole resonances together Decker et al. (2015); Campione et al. (2015); Liu et al. (2017); Arslan et al. (2017). However, requiring perfect anomalous transmission without reflection using Huygens’ metasurfaces results in globally lossless, but locally active or lossy, surface characterizations Epstein and Eleftheriades (2016a). It was found that an ΩΩ\Omega-type bianisotropic metasurface is capable of achieving perfect anomalous refraction without loss or reflection Wong et al. (2016); Epstein and Eleftheriades (2016b); Asadchy et al. (2016). Similarly for reflective metasurfaces, an anomalous reflector based on the generalized Snell’s law Yu et al. (2011) cannot perfectly reflect an incident plane wave into an anomalous direction, but necessarily entails parasitic reflections into undesired directions Mohammadi Estakhri and Alù (2016); Asadchy et al. (2016). Again, requiring that the reflected wave be a single plane wave in the desired anomalous direction results in a strongly dispersive reflecting surface with local active-lossy characteristics. Towards achieving perfect reflection using passive metasurfaces, a reflector design approach based on the leaky-wave antenna principle has been recently reported Díaz-Rubio et al. (2017), where a measured reflection power efficiency of 94% has been realized using a printed patch array implementation.

For penetrable metasurfaces, a design recipe for passive, lossless ΩΩ\Omega-type bianisotropic metasurfaces has been introduced Epstein and Eleftheriades (2016b, c). It was shown that an envisioned wave transformation is supported by a lossless ΩΩ\Omega-type bianisotropic metasurface if power is locally conserved. By introducing auxiliary SWs for equalizing the power on both sides of the surface, designs for a perfect beam split as well as anomalous reflection and refraction have been numerically demonstrated. The same design methodology was applied to a metasurface over a perfect electric conductor surface for perfect anomalous reflection Epstein and Eleftheriades (2017). The design philosophy has been recently extended to lossless, impenetrable surfaces characterized by a reactive surface impedance for perfect reflection control of plane waves Kwon and Tretyakov (2017), where SWs of an orthogonal polarization were chosen. Recently, a metasurface design study toward perfect conversion between a plane wave and an SW has been reported Tcvetkova et al. (2017). In Achouri and Caloz (2016a, b), metasurface designs for SW routing of beams were presented for transmissive metasurfaces. Starting from the generalized sheet transition conditions, spatially-dispersive susceptibilities of the metasurface were specified in terms of the desired field discontinuities. However, such metasurface designs have spatially varying surface parameters with alternately active and lossy properties, posing a challenge for realization.

This paper presents a design technique for passive, lossless impenetrable metasurfaces for perfect beam manipulation. It relies on synthesis of an evanescent auxiliary wave such that the total fields on the metasurface have no real power component through the surface everywhere. It is shown that evanescent waves having a spatially growing and diminishing envelope along the propagation direction can receive and launch PWs, respectively. The exact power profile of this custom SW is determined for a given desired set of illuminating (input) and radiating (output) waves via an efficient numerical optimization procedure. As a natural extension of infinite, periodic metasurface designs for plane waves Kwon and Tretyakov (2017), a treatment of beam manipulation not only provides a design recipe for transforming arbitrary incident waves having a continuum of spectrum, but also demonstrates the versatility of metasurfaces in wave manipulation that is achievable with passive realizations. The design produces an inhomogeneous, anisotropic surface reactance tensor, which may be approximately realized using the standard printed circuit technologies.

II Beam control: perfect receiving, guiding, and launching

Figure 1 illustrates the design problem for an impenetrable metasurface under consideration. In free space, a known beam wave illuminates a planar impenetrable surface in the x​z𝑥𝑧xz-plane. Using a passive, lossless metasurface, it desired that the incident beam is first received and converted into an SW, subsequently guided along the surface, before it is launched back into space from a location that is electrically far separated from the receiving point. The power of the desired output wave is the same as that of the incident beam. Furthermore, a surface with reciprocal parameters is desired.

At the heart of the design lies perfect conversion of a PW into an SW and a subsequent transition into lossless guiding along the surface. Launching is a reciprocal process of receiving and a planar structure with a uniform reactive surface impedance can guide an SW without loss. For such a converter based on the generalized Snell’s law, it was found that an SW, once generated, cannot propagate along the gradient metasurface without suffering secondary scattering by the same metasurface back into space. This lowers the conversion efficiency for electrically long converters Qu et al. (2013), defined for the power accepted by a homogeneous guiding metasurface. The conversion efficiency is significantly improved by introducing a meta-coupler at a height over a homogeneous surface that supports a surface wave Sun et al. (2016). A drawback of this approach is an increased overall thickness. Nevertheless, the conversion efficiency cannot reach 100% because some of the generated SW fields still undergo secondary scattering by the meta-coupler.

Instead of relying on the generalized reflection law, designing the exact SW tailored to the incident wave can lead to a metasurface design that is capable of perfect PW-to-SW conversion. With respect to the chosen guided direction (the +x𝑥+x-axis direction in Fig. 1), this custom SW must have a position-dependent amplitude profile such that the amplitude grows over the range of beam illumination due to PW-to-SW conversion, stays constant over the guided range without leakage radiation, then diminishes over the range of beam launch due to SW-to-PW conversion. Over the beam receiving range, the PW is continuously converted into the SW, so there is no abrupt junction between conversion and guiding ranges. The exact profile of the SW is determined such that the PW-to-SW conversion is done in a locally lossless manner, without loss in or power supplied by the metasurface, everywhere on the surface. Once the exact SW is designed, the boundary condition for the impenetrable surface is found for supporting the envisioned total fields as a reactive surface impedance.

In this work, the same polarization is chosen between the input and output beams. For the surface wave, an orthogonal polarization is chosen as in Kwon and Tretyakov (2017); Tcvetkova et al. (2017). An orthogonally polarized SW avoids creating an interference power pattern between the PW and SW on the surface, simplifying the SW synthesis significantly. In the following sections, beam controlling metasurfaces in two-dimensional (2-D) configurations with PWs in the TE polarization (with respect to y𝑦y) and SWs in the TM polarization are presented.

This reactance tensor represents a lossless, reciprocal surface if the off-diagonal terms are equal to each other. This condition is equivalent to Kwon and Tretyakov (2017)

where Snsubscript𝑆𝑛S_{n} is the normal component of the Poynting vector on the surface. Hence, if there is no net power penetrating the surface at a given point either as absorption by the surface (Sn<0)subscript𝑆𝑛0(S_{n}<0) or as power injected into y>0𝑦0y>0 by a source on the surface(Sn>0)subscript𝑆𝑛0(S_{n}>0), the surface is locally lossless and reciprocal. If (4) is satisfied everywhere, the metasurface is lossless and reciprocal globally.

The reactance tensor of a lossless surface is in general a Hermitian tensor. Therefore, a real, symmetric tensor in (3) under the condition (4) is not the unique solution for a lossless, reciprocal surface that supports (𝐄,𝐇)𝐄𝐇(\mathbf{E},\mathbf{H}) because the off-diagonal elements were set to have no imaginary parts by design. Still, a symmetric 𝐗ssubscript𝐗𝑠\mathbf{X}_{s} with real-valued elements is advantageous because its eigenvalues are real and the eigenvectors are orthogonal, allowing realization using an array of rotated resonant meta-atoms.

IV Synthesis of the surface wave

In Fig. 1, consider a 2-D configuration where the input and output PW fields are TE-polarized and the SW field is TM-polarized with all the fields invariant along the z𝑧z-axis. Then, Ez​(x,y)subscript𝐸𝑧𝑥𝑦E_{z}(x,y) and Hz​(x,y)subscript𝐻𝑧𝑥𝑦H_{z}(x,y) uniquely determine all remaining field components in the x​y𝑥𝑦xy-plane for the TE and TM polarizations, respectively. The electromagnetic uniqueness theorem allows the fields in the half space y≥0𝑦0y\geq 0, which is bounded by the metasurface and subject to the radiation condition at infinity, to be uniquely determined from those on the metasurface at y=0𝑦0y=0. Furthermore, the planar metasurface geometry makes analysis and design in the spectral domain efficient via Fourier transform. Derivations for field components and the normal component of the Poynting vector are available in Appendices A and B for TE- and TM-mode fields, respectively.

The metasurface design starts from a complete knowledge of the incident beam and the desired output beam. For a given input beam, we assume that the output PW fields are known from a separate overall function design of the metasurface. In particular, the total output power should be equal to the input power in order to make the overall system lossless. In terms of Et​z​(x)subscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥E_{tz}(x) and its Fourier transform E~t​z​(kx)=ℱ​{Et​z​(x)}subscript~𝐸𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥ℱsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥\tilde{E}_{tz}(k_{x})=\mathscr{F}\{E_{tz}(x)\}, the expression for the normal component of the time-average Poynting vector is given in (26), which can be written compactly as

SyTE​(x)=12​k​η​Re⁡{Et​z∗​(x)​ℱ−1​[ky​E~t​z​(kx)]}.subscriptsuperscript𝑆TE𝑦𝑥12𝑘𝜂Resuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥superscriptℱ1delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑦subscript~𝐸𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥S^{\text{TE}}_{y}(x)=\frac{1}{2k\eta}\operatorname{Re}\left\{E_{tz}^{*}(x)\mathscr{F}^{-1}\left[k_{y}\tilde{E}_{tz}(k_{x})\right]\right\}. (5)

Typically, closed-form field expressions are approximate and available only in the paraxial region near the beam axis, even for commonly studied beams such as Gaussian or Bessel beams. Hence, the primary quantities for analysis and design are z𝑧z-directed field components on the metasurface in this study.

For the TE-polarized input and output fields in a typical beam control application described in Fig. 1, the normal power density profile is illustrated in Fig. 2(a) as a red dashed curve. For a beam wave having a finite support, we can define the lower and upper x𝑥x-limits for the input wave, xilsubscript𝑥ilx_{\text{il}} and xiusubscript𝑥iux_{\text{iu}}, such that non-negligible fields and power are observed in x∈[xil,xiu]𝑥subscript𝑥ilsubscript𝑥iux\in[x_{\text{il}},x_{\text{iu}}]. Similarly, two x𝑥x-coordinates are set to define the range where the output beam leaves the surface to be x∈[xol,xou]𝑥subscript𝑥olsubscript𝑥oux\in[x_{\text{ol}},x_{\text{ou}}]. The objective of the SW synthesis is to design a custom SW, specified by Ht​z​(x)subscript𝐻𝑡𝑧𝑥H_{tz}(x) in −∞<x<∞𝑥-\infty<x<\infty, such that (4) is satisfied for all x𝑥x. Choosing an orthogonal TM polarization for the SW makes the normal Poynting vector component of the total fields equal to an algebraic sum of the TE and TM polarization components, i.e.,

In Fig. 2(a), the target power profile for the TM-polarized SW is shown as a solid blue curve. For Ht​z​(x)subscript𝐻𝑡𝑧𝑥H_{tz}(x), we choose propagating function in the +x𝑥+x direction with a custom x𝑥x-dependent envelope. This envelope function is a real function, taking non-negative values. A snapshot of Ht​z​(x)subscript𝐻𝑡𝑧𝑥H_{tz}(x) (the real part) is visualized as a thin gray curve in Fig. 2(b). At this point, it is instructive to assess the qualitative behavior of the synthesized SW in y≥0𝑦0y\geq 0. The definition of Ht​z​(x)subscript𝐻𝑡𝑧𝑥H_{tz}(x) with respect to the envelope A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) in (9) relates their Fourier transforms as

H~t​z​(kx)=A~​(kx−kc).subscript~𝐻𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥~𝐴subscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘𝑐\tilde{H}_{tz}(k_{x})=\tilde{A}(k_{x}-k_{c}). (10)

Since A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) is a real, non-negative function of x𝑥x, A~​(kx)~𝐴subscript𝑘𝑥\tilde{A}(k_{x}) has the maximum at kx=0subscript𝑘𝑥0k_{x}=0. While a finite spatial support of A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) makes A~​(kx)~𝐴subscript𝑘𝑥\tilde{A}(k_{x}) not completely vanish at large |kx|subscript𝑘𝑥|k_{x}|, the effective spectral width of A~​(kx)~𝐴subscript𝑘𝑥\tilde{A}(k_{x}) is inversely proportional to the range of non-zero A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x). From (27), the resulting H-field component of the SW in y≥0𝑦0y\geq 0 is expressed as

Hz​(x,y)=12​π​∫−∞∞A~​(kx−kc)​e−j​(kx​x+ky​y)​𝑑kx.subscript𝐻𝑧𝑥𝑦12𝜋superscriptsubscript~𝐴subscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘𝑐superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑘𝑥𝑥subscript𝑘𝑦𝑦differential-dsubscript𝑘𝑥H_{z}(x,y)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{A}(k_{x}-k_{c})e^{-j(k_{x}x+k_{y}y)}dk_{x}. (11)

It can be seen that the dominant contribution to Hz​(x,y)subscript𝐻𝑧𝑥𝑦H_{z}(x,y) comes from its spectrum at and around kx=kcsubscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘𝑐k_{x}=k_{c}. At kx=kcsubscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘𝑐k_{x}=k_{c}, the integrand in (11) represents a surface wave bound to the y=0𝑦0y=0 surface with a positive propagation constant of kx=kcsubscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘𝑐k_{x}=k_{c} in the x𝑥x-direction and an attenuation constant of |ky|=kc2−k2subscript𝑘𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑐2superscript𝑘2|k_{y}|=\sqrt{k_{c}^{2}-k^{2}} in the y𝑦y-direction. Over the beam reception and launch ranges, the amplitude of the SW grows and diminishes gradually with respect to x𝑥x, respectively. In both ranges, the SW propagates in the +x𝑥+x-direction and attenuates exponentially in the +y𝑦+y-direction. Finally, contributions from all other spectral ranges make the SW exist over the intended, finite range of x𝑥x.

Requiring A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) to be a continuous function, it remains to determine the functions, Ai​(x)subscript𝐴i𝑥A_{\text{i}}(x) and Ao​(x)subscript𝐴o𝑥A_{\text{o}}(x), and the constant A0subscript𝐴0A_{0}. For Ai​(x)subscript𝐴i𝑥A_{\text{i}}(x), we choose a closely spaced set of Ncisubscript𝑁ciN_{\text{ci}} control points of values Ansubscript𝐴𝑛A_{n} at locations x=xc​n𝑥subscript𝑥c𝑛x=x_{\text{c}n} (n=−Nci,−Nci+1,…,−1)𝑛subscript𝑁cisubscript𝑁ci1…1(n=-N_{\text{ci}},-N_{\text{ci}}+1,\ldots,-1). Similarly, Ncosubscript𝑁coN_{\text{co}} number of control points of values Ansubscript𝐴𝑛A_{n} at x=xc​n𝑥subscript𝑥c𝑛x=x_{\text{c}n} (n=1,2,…,Nco)𝑛12…subscript𝑁co(n=1,2,\ldots,N_{\text{co}}) are defined for Ao​(x)subscript𝐴o𝑥A_{\text{o}}(x). The constant level at A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} should make smooth connections to the transition ranges on both sides. A continuous envelope function is then defined using these control points (locations and values) via interpolation. No control points are assigned at the boundary locations of the input and output beam ranges. In Fig. 2(b), control points are indicated by red circles. The number and x𝑥x-locations of the control points are set appropriately by the designer depending on the allowed complexity of the synthesized SW.

Efficient numerical optimizations can determine the values of Ansubscript𝐴𝑛A_{n} (n=−Nci,…,Nco)𝑛subscript𝑁ci…subscript𝑁co(n=-N_{\text{ci}},\ldots,N_{\text{co}}). In this work, a square error function defined by

error=∫−∞∞|SyTE​(x)+SyTM​(x)|2​𝑑xerrorsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑆TE𝑦𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑆TM𝑦𝑥2differential-d𝑥\text{error}=\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}|S^{\text{TE}}_{y}(x)+S^{\text{TM}}_{y}(x)|^{2}dx (12)

is minimized with respect to the Nci+Nco+1subscript𝑁cisubscript𝑁co1N_{\text{ci}}+N_{\text{co}}+1 number of control point values. Specifically, a gradient-free optimization method available through the fminsearch function in Matlab has been used for all designs presented in Sec. V. After some adjustments to the number and locations of control points, all optimizations converged within a convergence tolerance of 10−6superscript10610^{-6} relative to the error associated with a null initial guess.

Once the optimized envelope function A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) is determined, using Ht​z​(x)subscript𝐻𝑡𝑧𝑥H_{tz}(x) from (9) in (28) at y=0𝑦0y=0 finds Et​x​(x)subscript𝐸𝑡𝑥𝑥E_{tx}(x). Together with Et​z​(x)subscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥E_{tz}(x) and Ht​x​(x)subscript𝐻𝑡𝑥𝑥H_{tx}(x) given by the TE-mode fields, they determine the surface reactance tensor that achieves the designed beam control via (3).

Since a spatially varying envelope function is used, the synthesized SW has a continuum of spectrum concentrated around kx=kcsubscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘ck_{x}=k_{\text{c}} rather than a discrete spectrum. As a result, some of the spectrum will spill into the visible region (|kx|<k)subscript𝑘𝑥𝑘(|k_{x}|<k). This means that satisfaction of (4) for all x𝑥x, or equivalently the resulting passive, lossless metasurface, necessarily entails excitation of extra PW components in order to to perform the required beam manipulation. The amount of TM-polarized PW components can be assessed by evaluating the total TM-mode power per unit length in the z𝑧z-axis direction that escapes the metasurface. This power, denoted PyTMsubscriptsuperscript𝑃TM𝑦P^{\text{TM}}_{y}, is found to have a spectral integral representation given by

PyTM=∫−∞∞SyTM​(x)​𝑑x=∫−∞∞Re⁡{η​ky4​π​k​|H~t​z​(kx)|2}​𝑑kx.subscriptsuperscript𝑃TM𝑦superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑆TM𝑦𝑥differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscriptRe𝜂subscript𝑘𝑦4𝜋𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝐻𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥2differential-dsubscript𝑘𝑥P^{\text{TM}}_{y}=\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}S^{\text{TM}}_{y}(x)dx=\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\operatorname{Re}\left\{\frac{\eta k_{y}}{4\pi k}|\tilde{H}_{tz}(k_{x})|^{2}\right\}dk_{x}. (13)

It can be seen that non-zero TM-mode spectrum in the visible region leads to some TM-mode power that is not bound to the metasurface. In principle, this amount of TM-polarized PW components can be reduced to approach zero by increasing kcsubscript𝑘ck_{\text{c}} deep into the invisible range. However, this results in faster spatial variations for the surface impedance tensor elements, making an accurate realization more challenging.

V Design examples

In the following examples, a metasurface design is characterized as a tensor surface impedance 𝐙s​(x)subscript𝐙𝑠𝑥\mathbf{Z}_{s}(x), given in terms of the reactance tensor elements in (2). In numerical validations using COMSOL Multiphysics, the impedance boundary condition (1) is enforced at y=0𝑦0y=0.

V.1 Gaussian beam translator-reflector

As a first design example, a translator-reflector for receiving and launching a Gaussian beam (GB) propagating normal to the metasurface is presented. The specific design function is illustrated in Fig. 3(a). A 2-D GB propagating in the −y𝑦-y-axis direction illuminates the metasurface with the beam axis aimed at x=−10​λ𝑥10𝜆x=-10\lambda, where λ𝜆\lambda is the free-space wavelength. The output beam is a GB of the same beam specification that is launched normally into free space from x=10​λ𝑥10𝜆x=10\lambda, after being translated in the +x𝑥+x-axis direction. The tangent vector of the input electric field on the surface is specified by

𝐄ti​(x)=𝐄0i​e−(x+10​λ)2/2​σ2;𝐄0i=z^​V/m,σ=2​λ.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝐄i𝑡𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝐄i0superscript𝑒superscript𝑥10𝜆22superscript𝜎2formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝐄i0^𝑧V/m𝜎2𝜆\mathbf{E}^{\text{i}}_{t}(x)=\mathbf{E}^{\text{i}}_{0}e^{-(x+10\lambda)^{2}/2\sigma^{2}};\ \ \mathbf{E}^{\text{i}}_{0}=\hat{z}~{}\text{V/m},\ \sigma=2\lambda. (14)

Equation (14) completely specifies the incident fields in y≥0𝑦0y\geq 0. The minimum waist of the input beam is equal to 2​σ=2​2​λ2𝜎22𝜆\sqrt{2}\sigma=2\sqrt{2}\lambda and it is located in the x​z𝑥𝑧xz-plane. The tangential vector of the output beam is specified to be

𝐄to​(x)=𝐄0o​e−(x−10​λ)2/2​σ2,𝐄0o=z^​V/m.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝐄o𝑡𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝐄o0superscript𝑒superscript𝑥10𝜆22superscript𝜎2subscriptsuperscript𝐄o0^𝑧V/m\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{t}(x)=\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{0}e^{-(x-10\lambda)^{2}/2\sigma^{2}},\ \ \mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{0}=\hat{z}~{}\text{V/m}. (15)

The same amplitude vector and beam waist guarantee that the output power per unit length in z𝑧z is equal to that of the input beam.

For each beam, we treat the decayed fields at positions away from the beam axis by more than 3​σ3𝜎3\sigma, where the field amplitude reduces to 1.1% of the peak value, as zero and thus choose xil=−16​λsubscript𝑥il16𝜆x_{\text{il}}=-16\lambda, xiu=−4​λsubscript𝑥iu4𝜆x_{\text{iu}}=-4\lambda, xol=4​λsubscript𝑥ol4𝜆x_{\text{ol}}=4\lambda, and xou=16​λsubscript𝑥ou16𝜆x_{\text{ou}}=16\lambda. Next, the center wavenumber is chosen to be kc=2​ksubscript𝑘c2𝑘k_{\text{c}}=2k. Due to the symmetry of the problem, an even symmetry for A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) is enforced with respect to x𝑥x. A total of 17 independent control points, Ansubscript𝐴𝑛A_{n} (n=−16,−15,…,−1)𝑛1615…1(n=-16,-15,\ldots,-1) in x∈[xil,xiu]𝑥subscript𝑥ilsubscript𝑥iux\in[x_{\text{il}},x_{\text{iu}}] and A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} at x=0𝑥0x=0, are assigned. An equal spacing was chosen between the 16 points, xnsubscript𝑥𝑛x_{n} (n=−16,−15,…,−1)𝑛1615…1(n=-16,-15,\ldots,-1). Numerical optimization was performed for the 17 control point values. In fact, the power profiles and envelope function shown in Fig. 2 display the optimization results of this design drawn to scale. As can be observed in Fig. 2(a), SyTEsubscriptsuperscript𝑆TE𝑦S^{\text{TE}}_{y} and SyTMsubscriptsuperscript𝑆TM𝑦S^{\text{TM}}_{y} effectively cancel each other. For the optimized envelope, it was found that A0=16.5​mA/msubscript𝐴016.5mA/mA_{0}=16.5~{}\text{mA/m} and other values scale according to Fig. 2(b).

The elements of 𝐗ssubscript𝐗𝑠\mathbf{X}_{s} of the optimized design were computed over −20​λ<x<20​λ20𝜆𝑥20𝜆-20\lambda<x<20\lambda. Figure 3(b) shows its four elements in 9​λ<x<11​λ9𝜆𝑥11𝜆9\lambda<x<11\lambda, where SW-to-PW conversion occurs. They are highly spatially dispersive functions. The values diverge four times over one wavelength, where the denominator in (3) becomes zero. The spatial frequency of diverging reactance elements is a result of the choice kcsubscript𝑘ck_{\text{c}} combined with the uniform phase of Ht​xsubscript𝐻𝑡𝑥H_{tx} associated with broadside launching. As expected for a lossless design, it is observed that Xx​z=Xz​xsubscript𝑋𝑥𝑧subscript𝑋𝑧𝑥X_{xz}=X_{zx}. In comparison, the x𝑥x-range near the origin corresponds to guidance of a TM wave in the absence of any TE components. The reactance elements over −λ<x<λ𝜆𝑥𝜆-\lambda<x<\lambda are plotted in Fig. 3(c). Here, with only a TM-mode SW present, it is noted that Ht​x=0subscript𝐻𝑡𝑥0H_{tx}=0, Et​z=0subscript𝐸𝑡𝑧0E_{tz}=0, and Re⁡{Et​x​Ht​z∗}=0Resubscript𝐸𝑡𝑥superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡𝑧0\operatorname{Re}\{E_{tx}H_{tz}^{*}\}=0 in (3). A tensor impedance representation is not appropriate in such a case. In numerical evaluation, (3) may be understood as a limiting case where TE-polarized components approach zero. Still, some numerical artifact is observed in that Xx​z≠Xz​xsubscript𝑋𝑥𝑧subscript𝑋𝑧𝑥X_{xz}\neq X_{zx} in Fig. 3(c). Since there are no TE-polarized components in this range, only the terms Xx​xsubscript𝑋𝑥𝑥X_{xx} and Xz​xsubscript𝑋𝑧𝑥X_{zx} are significant. Since Xz​x=0subscript𝑋𝑧𝑥0X_{zx}=0, no z𝑧z-directed (TE-polarized) electric field will be generated from an x𝑥x-directed electric current. A constant inductive self-reactance at Xx​x=1.73​ηsubscript𝑋𝑥𝑥1.73𝜂X_{xx}=1.73\eta is consistent with a TM-mode surface wave having a propagation constant of kc=2​ksubscript𝑘c2𝑘k_{\text{c}}=2k. In the guided TM-polarized SW range, the tensor surface impedance may well be replaced by an isotropic reactive impedance 𝐙s=𝐈t​j​Xx​xsubscript𝐙𝑠subscript𝐈𝑡𝑗subscript𝑋𝑥𝑥\mathbf{Z}_{s}=\mathbf{I}_{t}jX_{xx} (𝐈t=an identity tensor in the x​y-plane)subscript𝐈𝑡an identity tensor in the xy-plane(\mathbf{I}_{t}=\text{an identity tensor in the $xy$-plane}). This isotropic choice of 𝐙ssubscript𝐙𝑠\mathbf{Z}_{s} over the constant-amplitude SW range, xiu<x<xolsubscript𝑥iu𝑥subscript𝑥olx_{\text{iu}}<x<x_{\text{ol}}, was also tested in numerical analysis. The resulting field distributions (not shown) are found to be the same as the case where the fully-anisotropic impedance was used.

The scattering characteristics of the metasurface is simulated using COMSOL Multiphysics. Illuminated by the GB the metasurface was designed for, Fig. 4(a) plots a snapshot of Ezsubscript𝐸𝑧E_{z} over an area of |x|<20​λ𝑥20𝜆|x|<20\lambda, 0<y<16​λ0𝑦16𝜆0<y<16\lambda. Over the illuminated range by the input GB, no reflection is seen with only the incident beam field being observed. In the output GB launch range, the desired GB with the same strength and beam waist is radiated. A snapshot of Hzsubscript𝐻𝑧H_{z} is shown in Fig. 4(b). Non-zero fields are observed tightly bound to the y=0𝑦0y=0 surface. In the inset on the right, a magnified view of the Hzsubscript𝐻𝑧H_{z} snapshot is shown over 8​λ<x<12​λ8𝜆𝑥12𝜆8\lambda<x<12\lambda in the SW-to-PW conversion range. A surface wave with a diminishing amplitude is induced as designed. Over the guided SW range shown in the inset on the left, a TM-polarized SW of a constant amplitude is clearly visible. Over the input beam reception range (a magnified view not shown), the amplitude of the SW gradually grows. In Fig. 4(c), the magnitude of the SW field spectrum is plotted with respect to kxsubscript𝑘𝑥k_{x} in both the visible (|kx|≤k)subscript𝑘𝑥𝑘(|k_{x}|\leq k) and invisible (|kx|>k)subscript𝑘𝑥𝑘(|k_{x}|>k) ranges. The spectrum is strongly concentrated around the maximum at kx=kc=2​ksubscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘c2𝑘k_{x}=k_{\text{c}}=2k. The shape of the SW spectrum is completely determined by the envelope function because H~t​z​(kx)=ℱ​{A​(x)​e−j​kc​x}=A~​(kx−kc)subscript~𝐻𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥ℱ𝐴𝑥superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑘c𝑥~𝐴subscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘c\tilde{H}_{tz}(k_{x})=\mathscr{F}\{A(x)e^{-jk_{\text{c}}x}\}=\tilde{A}(k_{x}-k_{\text{c}}). Computed using (13), the power associated with the TM-polarized PW component from the visible range is six orders of magnitude below that of the input GB power. Hence, the synthesized TM-polarized SW can be considered completely bound to the reflecting surface.

V.2 Probe current-fed Gaussian beam launcher

A uniform-amplitude SW can be generated by a localized source. Via reciprocity, an SW can be absorbed by a localized lossy material or load impedance. When combined with the PW-to-SW conversion, such a device represents a leaky-wave antenna that transmits or receives a beam wave.

Here, a GB launcher in an oblique angle is designed. For this purpose, the GB translator-reflector of Sec. V.1 can be adapted to design an oblique GB launcher excited by an input beam, before the SW feeding mechanism is replaced with a localized current probe. The underlying GB launcher configuration is illustrated in Fig. 5(a). The input beam remains unchanged from the translator-reflector design in Sec. V.1. The output beam shape remains the same, but it is launched at an angle of ψ0subscript𝜓0\psi_{0} from the surface normal from x=10​λ𝑥10𝜆x=10\lambda. The output beam can be first characterized in a rotated (u,v,w)𝑢𝑣𝑤(u,v,w) coordinate system with respect to z=w𝑧𝑤z=w such that the v𝑣v-axis is aligned with the output beam axis. Along the u𝑢u-axis, the output GB is completely characterized by the w𝑤w-component of the electric field

𝐄to​(u)=𝐄0o​e−u2/2​σ2,𝐄0o=w^​V/m.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝐄o𝑡𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐄o0superscript𝑒superscript𝑢22superscript𝜎2subscriptsuperscript𝐄o0^𝑤V/m\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{t}(u)=\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{0}e^{-u^{2}/2\sigma^{2}},\ \ \mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{0}=\hat{w}~{}\text{V/m}. (16)

Then, the output beam fields in the entire u​v𝑢𝑣uv-plane can be obtained by applying the relations in Appendix A in the u​v𝑢𝑣uv-plane. A special care should be exercised so that the fields in the range v<0𝑣0v<0 represent a propagating wave with kv>0subscript𝑘𝑣0k_{v}>0. This can be done by taking a complex conjugate of the fields from Appendix A, corresponding to a time-reversal transformation. Fields evaluated along the x𝑥x-axis in the u​v𝑢𝑣uv-plane can be transformed to the x​y​z𝑥𝑦𝑧xyz system by a proper coordinate rotation, before they can be used for the device design in the x​y𝑥𝑦xy-plane.

For a 30° GB launcher (ψ0=30​°)subscript𝜓030°(\psi_{0}=30\degree), the x𝑥x-range of numerical synthesis of the envelope function was set with xil=−16​λsubscript𝑥il16𝜆x_{\text{il}}=-16\lambda, xiu=−4​λsubscript𝑥iu4𝜆x_{\text{iu}}=-4\lambda, xol=3.75​λsubscript𝑥ol3.75𝜆x_{\text{ol}}=3.75\lambda, and xou=16.25​λsubscript𝑥ou16.25𝜆x_{\text{ou}}=16.25\lambda. For the output beam, the range was slightly extended to account for the oblique launch angle. In each of x∈[xil,xiu]𝑥subscript𝑥ilsubscript𝑥iux\in[x_{\text{il}},x_{\text{iu}}] and x∈[xol,xou]𝑥subscript𝑥olsubscript𝑥oux\in[x_{\text{ol}},x_{\text{ou}}], 15 equally-spaced control points were assigned. Hence, together with A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} assigned to x=0𝑥0x=0, a total of 31 control points were defined for A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) and they were optimized for the minimum square error (12). The center wavenumber was chosen to be kc=2​ksubscript𝑘c2𝑘k_{\text{c}}=2k. The optimized envelope function together with the control points are plotted in Fig. 5(b). The amplitude of the guided SW was found to be A0=16.5​mA/msubscript𝐴016.5mA/mA_{0}=16.5~{}\text{mA/m}, which remains unchanged from the translator-reflector design in Sec. V.1 as can be expected. In Fig. 5(c), the reactance tensor elements over 9​λ<x<11​λ9𝜆𝑥11𝜆9\lambda<x<11\lambda in the oblique GB launch range are plotted. They are different from Fig. 3(b) and they diverge less frequently with respect to x𝑥x. This is due to different phase gradients present in Ht​xsubscript𝐻𝑡𝑥H_{tx} in (3) for the same SW expected in the two designs. Indicative of a lossless property, Xx​z=Xz​xsubscript𝑋𝑥𝑧subscript𝑋𝑧𝑥X_{xz}=X_{zx} is observed.

Since launching the output GB using a localized source is of interest, we adopt a localized source in the form of a two-element array around x=0𝑥0x=0. In other words, the +x𝑥+x-propagating constant-amplitude SW near x=0𝑥0x=0 is provided by a current probe instead of an input GB. Two elementary radiators separated by a quarter wavelength with a 90° phase difference can create a unidirectional radiation pattern Balanis (2005). Hence, denoting the attenuation constant of the SW around x=0𝑥0x=0 by αcsubscript𝛼c\alpha_{\text{c}}, we use an impressed electric current source given by

𝐉imp=y^​J0​e−αc​y​[δ​(x+λc8)​ej​π4+δ​(x−λc8)​e−j​π4]subscript𝐉imp^𝑦subscript𝐽0superscript𝑒subscript𝛼c𝑦delimited-[]𝛿𝑥subscript𝜆c8superscript𝑒𝑗𝜋4𝛿𝑥subscript𝜆c8superscript𝑒𝑗𝜋4\mathbf{J}_{\text{imp}}=\hat{y}J_{0}e^{-\alpha_{\text{c}}y}\left[\delta\left(x+\frac{\lambda_{\text{c}}}{8}\right)e^{j\frac{\pi}{4}}+\delta\left(x-\frac{\lambda_{\text{c}}}{8}\right)e^{-j\frac{\pi}{4}}\right] (17)

in 0≤y≤λc/40𝑦subscript𝜆c40\leq y\leq\lambda_{\text{c}}/4 and zero in y>λc/4𝑦subscript𝜆c4y>\lambda_{\text{c}}/4, where λc=2​π/kcsubscript𝜆c2𝜋subscript𝑘c\lambda_{\text{c}}=2\pi/k_{\text{c}} is the guided wavelength of the SW. This model represents two strips of vertical electric current of a λc/4subscript𝜆c4\lambda_{\text{c}}/4 height. Their y𝑦y-dependence is matched to that of the TM SW for maximum coupling. In simulation results that follow, J0=1​A/msubscript𝐽01A/mJ_{0}=1~{}\text{A/m} has been used.

Snapshots of the z𝑧z-component of the total electric and magnetic fields are plotted in Fig. 6. In Fig. 6(a), a GB is launched from x=10​λ𝑥10𝜆x=10\lambda at an angle of 30° as desired. In the snapshot of Hzsubscript𝐻𝑧H_{z} in Fig. 6(b), the TM-mode wave is visible only as an evanescent wave bound to the surface. The left inset shows a magnified view near the two-element current source at x=0𝑥0x=0. The two short line segments in black indicate the source positions and their height. A constructive interference between the fields generated by the two strip currents produces a +x𝑥+x-propagating SW with a maximum amplitude of 1 A/m (realized on the surface) as designed. A destructive interference results in negligible excitation of an SW toward the −x𝑥-x-axis direction. The inset on the right shows a portion of the SW-to-PW conversion range. The SW amplitude is gradually reduced with increasing x𝑥x due to continuous leakage into space.

V.3 Gaussian beam-excited focusing lens

In order to demonstrate the versatility of the design technique, a focusing lens excited by the same normally incident GB considered in Sec. V.1 is designed. The desired wave transformation is illustrated in Fig. 7(a). A normally incident GB is converted into a TM-polarized SW in x<0𝑥0x<0. The converted SW is transformed into a converging cylindrical wave in the range xol<x<xousubscript𝑥ol𝑥subscript𝑥oux_{\text{ol}}<x<x_{\text{ou}}, where an envelop function e​(x)𝑒𝑥e(x) for |Et​z​(x)|subscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥|E_{tz}(x)| is introduced. On both ends within the range, a transition period of a length Dtrsubscript𝐷trD_{\text{tr}} in a raised cosine profile is defined for a smooth transition between unity and zero, as illustrated in Fig. 7(a). Specifically,

In order for the launched cylindrical wave to converge at a focal point (xf,yf)subscript𝑥fsubscript𝑦f(x_{\text{f}},y_{\text{f}}), a phase distribution for Et​zsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑧E_{tz} is introduced as

where ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0} is an arbitrary phase constant. Then, the tangential electric field for the output wave is defined to be

(20)

The amplitude E0osubscriptsuperscript𝐸o0E^{\text{o}}_{0} is determined to make the overall conversion from the input GB to the output focusing wave lossless.

For the TE-polarized GB input wave considered in Sec. V.1, a focusing lens with a focal point at (xf,yf)=(12​λ,10​λ)subscript𝑥fsubscript𝑦f12𝜆10𝜆(x_{\text{f}},y_{\text{f}})=(12\lambda,10\lambda) is designed using an SW-to-PW conversion range with xol=5​λsubscript𝑥ol5𝜆x_{\text{ol}}=5\lambda, xou=19​λsubscript𝑥ou19𝜆x_{\text{ou}}=19\lambda. With a choice of Dtr=2​λsubscript𝐷tr2𝜆D_{\text{tr}}=2\lambda, the x𝑥x-range of a constant-amplitude electric field for the output wave is 7​λ<x<17​λ7𝜆𝑥17𝜆7\lambda<x<17\lambda. The phase constant ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0} is set to zero. For this chosen profile of 𝐄to​(x)subscriptsuperscript𝐄o𝑡𝑥\mathbf{E}^{\text{o}}_{t}(x), by setting the output PW power equal to the input GB power, the amplitude is found to be E0o=0.569​V/msubscriptsuperscript𝐸o00.569V/mE^{\text{o}}_{0}=0.569~{}\text{V/m}. Next, Nci=15subscript𝑁ci15N_{\text{ci}}=15 control points are defined for the input range −16​λ<x<−4​λ16𝜆𝑥4𝜆-16\lambda<x<-4\lambda, four control points are assigned to both transition ranges in the output range. To the constant-amplitude range of 10​λ10𝜆10\lambda length, 14 control points are assigned. The total number of control points is 38 for this lens design. The envelop function A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) of the optimized design is shown in Fig. 7(b) together with the control points indicated by red circles. In 7​λ<x<17​λ7𝜆𝑥17𝜆7\lambda<x<17\lambda, where a TE-polarized aperture electric field of a uniform magnitude is synthesized, it is observed that A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) diminishes with an increasingly negative slope with respect to x𝑥x as the SW power is continuously lost to the output PW. The four reactance element values of the optimized design over 11​λ<x<13​λ11𝜆𝑥13𝜆11\lambda<x<13\lambda in the SW-to-PW conversion range are shown in Fig. 7(c) as highly spatially dispersive functions. The lossless nature of the metasurface lens is indicated by the fact Xx​z=Xz​xsubscript𝑋𝑥𝑧subscript𝑋𝑧𝑥X_{xz}=X_{zx}.

Figure 8 shows the simulated results for the lens obtained using COMSOL Multiphysics. A snapshot of the TE-component of the electric field is plotted in Fig. 8(a). Converging cylindrical waves form a focal point at (x,y)=(xf,yf)=(12​λ,10​λ)𝑥𝑦subscript𝑥fsubscript𝑦f12𝜆10𝜆(x,y)=(x_{\text{f}},y_{\text{f}})=(12\lambda,10\lambda) as designed. A snapshot of Hz​(x,y)subscript𝐻𝑧𝑥𝑦H_{z}(x,y) in Fig. 8(b) shows the TM-polarized field, which is tightly bound to the metasurface. In a magnified view in the range 15​λ<x<19​λ15𝜆𝑥19𝜆15\lambda<x<19\lambda, the SW wave is seen to be diminishing and disappearing as all of its guided power along the +x𝑥+x-direction is leaked into the PW spectrum.

VI Conclusion

Arbitrary polarization-preserving beam control using passive, lossless impenetrable metasurfaces has been presented. It is based on a custom SW in an orthogonal polarization designed to propagate along the surface. By finding an optimal spatial envelope for the SW such that there is zero normal component for the Poynting vector everywhere on the surface, a lossless metasurface can convert a PW into an SW, guide the SW unattenuated along the surface, and launch a PW via an SW-to-PW transformation. As specific design examples, a GB translator-reflector, a GB launcher excited by a localized source, and a GB-fed flat focusing lens have been presented. Lossless metasurfaces characterized by a reactance tensor in a plane may be realized using an array of rotated subwavelength resonators printed on a grounded dielectric substrate.

Availability of an orthogonal polarization for SW synthesis simplifies the design process owing to the orthogonality of power flow in the surface normal direction between the PW and SW on the metasurface. The same design approach can be envisioned for polarization-converting transformations between the input and output beams or for using an SW that is co-polarized with the input and output beams. SW synthesis in such a scenario is expected to be challenging due to the complex interference power pattern created by the co-polarized PW and SW components in the system.

At microwave frequencies, a planar array of rotated anisotropic printed conductor patch resonators on a grounded dielectric substrate is a promising configuration Fong et al. (2010); Minatti et al. (2012); Patel and Grbic (2013); Lee and Sievenpiper (2016) that allows accurate, low-cost fabrication for realizing the inhomogeneous, tensor surface impedances in this study.

Appendix A Spectral representations of fields and power density in TE polarization

For TE-polarized fields, the tangential electric field on the surface, Et​z​(x)=Ez​(x,y=0)subscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥subscript𝐸𝑧𝑥𝑦0E_{tz}(x)=E_{z}(x,y=0), is expressed as an inverse Fourier transform of its spectrum E~t​z​(kx)subscript~𝐸𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥\tilde{E}_{tz}(k_{x}) as

Et​z​(x)=ℱ−1​[E~t​z​(kx)]=12​π​∫−∞∞E~t​z​(kx)​e−j​kx​x​𝑑kx,subscript𝐸𝑡𝑧𝑥superscriptℱ1delimited-[]subscript~𝐸𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥12𝜋superscriptsubscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑘𝑥𝑥differential-dsubscript𝑘𝑥E_{tz}(x)=\mathscr{F}^{-1}[\tilde{E}_{tz}(k_{x})]=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{E}_{tz}(k_{x})e^{-jk_{x}x}dk_{x}, (21)

where kxsubscript𝑘𝑥k_{x} is the wavenumber in the x𝑥x-direction. Here, we add a tilde to a spatial function to indicate its Fourier transform in x𝑥x. Equation (21) represents a superposition of plane waves propagating in the x​y𝑥𝑦xy-plane over the x𝑥x-wavenumber kxsubscript𝑘𝑥k_{x}, evaluated at y=0𝑦0y=0. Hence, at any point (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) in y≥0𝑦0y\geq 0, the field Ez​(x,y)subscript𝐸𝑧𝑥𝑦E_{z}(x,y) is the same superposition of plane waves evaluated at (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) after a proper phase delay in the y𝑦y direction is incorporated to each plane wave component in the integrand of (21). In other words,

Ez​(x,y)=12​π​∫−∞∞E~t​z​(kx)​e−j​(kx​x+ky​y)​𝑑kx,subscript𝐸𝑧𝑥𝑦12𝜋superscriptsubscriptsubscript~𝐸𝑡𝑧subscript𝑘𝑥superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝑘𝑥𝑥subscript𝑘𝑦𝑦differential-dsubscript𝑘𝑥E_{z}(x,y)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int\limits_{-\infty}^{\infty}\tilde{E}_{tz}(k_{x})e^{-j(k_{x}x+k_{y}y)}dk_{x}, (22)

where

and k𝑘k is the free-space wavenumber. At an observation point (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y), (22) represents a superposition of propagating and evanescent plane waves. In (23), a choice of the negative branch for the square root for |kx|>ksubscript𝑘𝑥𝑘|k_{x}|>k guarantees an exponential decay toward y→∞→𝑦y\to\infty for each inhomogeneous plane wave component.
